sections.title: Introduction to OpMode Types
sections.content: FTC provides two main types of OpModes: Linear and Iterative. Understanding the differences between these types is crucial for choosing the right approach for your robot programming needs.

sections.title: OpMode Types Overview
sections.subtitle: Two main OpMode types in FTC:
items: Linear OpModes: Sequential execution with built-in delays
Iterative OpModes: Continuous loops with manual timing control
Linear OpModes: Easier to write and understand
Iterative OpModes: More control over execution timing
Linear OpModes: Better for beginners and simple tasks
Iterative OpModes: Better for complex, time-sensitive operations

sections.title: Linear OpModes
sections.content: Linear OpModes execute code sequentially, one line at a time, with automatic timing control. They are easier to write and understand, making them ideal for beginners and simple robot operations.

sections.title: Linear OpMode Characteristics
items: Sequential Execution: Code runs line by line in order
Automatic Timing: Built-in delays prevent overwhelming the system
Simple Structure: Easy to read and understand
Built-in Delays: sleep() method provides automatic timing
Beginner Friendly: Less complex than iterative OpModes
Good for Autonomous: Perfect for step-by-step autonomous sequences

sections.title: Linear OpMode Example
Iterative OpModes
sections.content: Iterative OpModes run in a continuous loop, giving you full control over timing and execution. They are more complex but provide greater flexibility for advanced robot operations.

sections.title: Iterative OpMode Characteristics
items: Continuous Loop: Code runs in a repeating loop
Manual Timing: You control all timing and delays
Real-time Control: Immediate response to inputs
Complex Logic: Can handle sophisticated algorithms
Performance Critical: Better for time-sensitive operations
Advanced Features: Supports complex state machines and PID control

sections.title: Iterative OpMode Example
Key Differences
sections.content: Understanding the key differences between Linear and Iterative OpModes helps you choose the right approach for your specific needs.

sections.title: Linear vs Iterative Comparison
items: Execution Model: Linear = Sequential, Iterative = Continuous loop
Timing Control: Linear = Automatic, Iterative = Manual
Complexity: Linear = Simple, Iterative = Complex
Performance: Linear = Good for simple tasks, Iterative = Better for complex tasks
Real-time Response: Linear = Limited, Iterative = Immediate
Learning Curve: Linear = Beginner-friendly, Iterative = Advanced

sections.title: Side-by-Side Comparison
When to Use Linear OpModes
sections.content: Linear OpModes are best suited for specific scenarios where simplicity and sequential execution are more important than real-time control.

sections.title: Linear OpMode Use Cases
items: Simple Autonomous: Basic movement sequences and routines
Beginner Programming: Learning FTC programming concepts
Testing and Debugging: Step-by-step testing of robot functions
Simple TeleOp: Basic driver control without complex features
Documentation: Clear, readable code for team reference
Quick Prototyping: Rapid development of basic functionality

sections.title: Linear OpMode Best Practices
When to Use Iterative OpModes
sections.content: Iterative OpModes are ideal for scenarios requiring real-time control, complex logic, or precise timing.

sections.title: Iterative OpMode Use Cases
items: Advanced TeleOp: Complex driver control with multiple features
PID Control: Precise motor control and positioning
Real-time Sensing: Continuous sensor monitoring and response
State Machines: Complex autonomous behaviors
Performance Critical: Time-sensitive operations
Advanced Features: Vision processing, advanced algorithms

sections.title: Iterative OpMode Best Practices
Converting Between OpMode Types
sections.content: Sometimes you need to convert between Linear and Iterative OpModes. Understanding the conversion process helps you adapt your code as your needs change.

sections.title: Conversion Considerations
items: Linear to Iterative: Replace sleep() with manual timing control
Iterative to Linear: Replace loop() with sequential execution
Method Structure: Adapt initialization and cleanup methods
Timing Control: Implement appropriate timing mechanisms
State Management: Handle state variables appropriately
Error Handling: Adapt error handling for the new structure

sections.title: Conversion Example
Choosing the Right OpMode Type
sections.subtitle: Use these guidelines to choose between Linear and Iterative OpModes:
items: Use Linear OpModes for simple, sequential operations
Use Iterative OpModes for complex, real-time control
Choose Linear for autonomous routines with fixed timing
Choose Iterative for TeleOp with immediate response needs
Use Linear for learning and debugging
Use Iterative for advanced features and performance
Consider team experience level when choosing
Start with Linear and upgrade to Iterative as needed
